title: backstop brexit plan irish border
story: But what is the fallback plan, and what does it mean for the Irish border? Heres what we know.The UK government is proposing a backstop arrangement which would keep the Irish border open after Brexit.Theres a need for such a fallback plan in the eventuality that no customs agreement has been decided on by March 2019, when the UK is due to leave the EU.And its seen as vital that a hard border is prevented between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland - which could happen were no deal struck and the two countries suddenly existed in different customs unions.Prime Minister Theresa May has said that she wants a wide-ranging free trade deal with the EU which would eliminate the need for regulatory checks on the Irish border.However, the EU is worried that the UKs vision could limit future trade deals, and not actually succeed in preventing the need for border infrastructure.The so-called backstop plans will outline a temporary customs arrangement with the EU in the eventuality that no permanent solution is agreed before the UKs March 2019 exit date.Full details of the UKs backstop proposal are set to be outlined in Parliament on Thursday, June 7.Cabinet sources confirmed that a four-page draft of the backstop plan had been circulated to ministers - prompting fresh rows within the Conservative Party over the apparent lack of end date to the plans.The EU believes the fallback option should be for Northern Ireland to stay in the single market for goods and the customs union until the UK has come up with a solution for the Irish border.This could keep Northern Ireland in the EU for some time after the rest of the UK has left - potentially around five years - and split the UK in half.But the Democratic Unionist Party, which props up the Conservative government, says it wont support any Brexit which results in divergence between NI and the rest of the UK.May relies on the DUP for their support in government - meaning agreeing to the EUs version of the backstop could destabilise her further.Under Mays vision, Britain would stop being an EU member state in March 2019, remain in the single market and customers until December 2020 and stay in the customs union for several more years after that.But Brussels has two issues with Mays plan.The first is that May wants the backstop to come to an end after a certain time period the EU think this would be self-defeating as its possible no solution for the Irish border would be found.The EU also thinks this risks leaving Britain benefiting from the customs union and single market for years after Brexit - reaping all the benefits without having any of the obligations that full membership would entail.One things for certain - therell be a lot more wrangling over this question yet.

title: italys new pm named as little known professor giuseppe conte

title: new uk road laws 8
story: AdvertorialNew UK road laws: 8 things ALL DRIVERS need to knowHere are the most important things to remember as the UK has a shakeup of driving rules&nbspShareByDave Masters00:00, 6 JUN 2018Updated12:06, 6 JUN 2018AdvertorialAll motorists need to brush up on the latest rules&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUK road laws are changing. Some new road laws have already come into place, with more set to change the way we look after our vehicles later this year. We've joined forces with the experts at Halfords to round up the essential bits of information all drivers need to know. So read on to stay up to date with the latest updates to British laws with this essential guide.  1. Learners can use the motorway now   For the first time learner drivers are allowed to take lessons on the motorway. Instructors must be properly licensed and have dual controls. This law should help learners become better prepared for driving on high speed roads - making our motorways safer. This follows a change in December which saw using a sat nav form part of the driving test. This was partly introduced because around a quarter of accidents involving new drivers are caused by them being distracted trying while using one. Tip: For added peace of mind, fit a dashcam. While they won't prevent an accident, investing in one can offer peace of mind. Having one means that if something were to happen, you'd have video evidence to back up your version of events. Because of this, they can even be used to lower your insurance premium. The Garmin 55 Dash Cam, above, is excellent, can wirelessly send footage to your phone and has amazing, better-than-HD quality video and superb low-light performance. 2. Your diesel must be clean  The quest to clean up diesel continues as MOTs are expanded to check particulate filters. If your car produces any visible smoke during the MOT then it will fail. Similarly if your particulate filter has been tampered with then you will also fail. Make sure your diesel is running well and as cleanly as possible before your test. Tip: Some diesel problems are complicated, but make sure your car has the right oil levels and is using the correct oil. Use the Halfords Oil Finder to pick the right oil for your car - or pop in to your local Halfords store for advice from their expert staff. You can also check the Halfords MOT Advice or book an MOT at a Halfords Autocentre.  3. There are penalties for driving in the wrong motorway lane   Smart motorways have lanes which can be opened and closed via electronic signs on the overhead gantry. This allows for better traffic flow during peak times by using the hard shoulder for additional capacity. If, however, you ignore the signs when a lane is closed you will be liable for a fixed penalty of &pound100 and three points. On many motorways you'll be automatically photographed if you break this rule and you'll get a fine as well as notice of penalty points in the post. Tip: A sat nav won't help with smart motorways, but they can alert you to possible traffic delays and reroute you. And with lifetime map updates, the Garmin Drive, above, is a great way to navigate.  4. Low tyre pressure is now an MOT fail  Before you go to your MOT make sure you've checked your tyre pressures are correct. MOT testers are on the lookout for tyres that are underinflated and aside from that it's important for safety to make sure your tyres are correctly inflated.  Tip: Make sure you have a tyre pressure checker at home so you can keep an eye on your tyres. A footpump or electric pump is a great way to keep tyres at the right pressure. 5. It's very easy to fail an MOT for a broken car bulb - get a Free Car Check to make sure they're working As many as 30 per cent of MOT fails are because of lighting or signalling problems. So make sure your horn works and walk around the car checking all the lights – make sure the car is parked safely and the handbrake is on first, or you can reverse up against a wall to check brake and reverse lights.  Tip: Halfords FREE Car Check will ensure your car bulbs are all working as they should. The check also includes:  Wiper Blades Check Car Bulb Check Battery Check Engine Oil Check Windscreen Chip Check Plus a FREE Screenwash Top Up  Just pop in to a store or book online now. 6. Headlight washers are crucial now  It might seem odd, but if your car has headlight washers fitted, and was registered after September 2009, then they must work. Tip: Halfords will top up your screen wash for free as part of the Free Car Check. The MOT also requires your wipers be fully working, and Halfords can check those too. There’s more info on wiper blades here.  7. In three years you'll need working daytime lights

title: dagenham ford equal pay strike
story: NewsHeroines of Dagenham Ford strike issue rallying cry to women as equal pay battle still rages 50 years onDagenham legends Eileen Pullen, 88, and Gwen Davis, 85, say women must keep fighting for their rights in the workplace&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer21:37, 5 JUN 2018Updated22:34, 5 JUN 2018NewsDagenham workers during the 1968 strike (Image: Phil Harris)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs the heroines of the Dagenham Ford plant equal pay strike &shycelebrate its 50th anniversary this week, their message for the next generation still fighting the same battle is simply: “Go for it.” Because half a century on, there is so much to be done – as proved by the recent #MeToo and Time’s Up campaigns and revelations about the continuing gender pay gap. Dagenham legend Eileen Pullen, 88, is delighted that her great-granddaughter’s generation are prepared to continue her fight for equality. “I’m all for it,” she says. “Things are a lot worse than I thought, women have a big fight in front of them. You can’t be frightened. “If you think you’re entitled to more pay, go for it.”  Eileen was one of the leaders when 185 female machinists at Dagenham, East London, went on strike in 1968 demanding an equal pay grading to their male colleagues. Tomorrow marks 50 years since the day the women, who stitched car seat covers, walked out. The covers soon ran out, halting production across the plant – proving just how integral their role was in the car manufacturing process. Their landmark action, immortalised in the 2010 film Made in Dagenham, is widely credited as a catalyst for the Equal Pay Act two years later. Yet despite being enshrined in law, equal pay has yet to be achieved in workplaces across the country.  The battle fought by Eileen and her colleagues continues today, as bosses are finally being forced to open up about the 18.4% gender pay gap that means women effectively work for free for two months each year. Fellow Dagenham striker Gwen Davis says: “It makes me angry and sad. Should we have to keep fighting for everything?” Gwen, 85, of Romford, East London, is frustrated that women are still subjected to lower pay and harassment at work. Like Eileen, she fully supports the high-profile campaigns that are calling out such ill treatment. “It should all be out in the open,” she says. “Why should a man think he has a right to your body?  “This year is about a lot of things, including equal pay – but overall, for women to be treated with respect. “Now women are protesting it’s revived my hope things will start to change. Women are strong compared to what they used to be, but it shouldn’t have taken 50 years. “I don’t think many people really understand what the word feminist means, still.” Pal Eileen, of nearby Rainham, encourages great-granddaughter Katie, a 20-year-old trainee nurse, to stand her ground. Eileen says: “I’ve been mad this year. I tell Katie to stick up for herself. I say to all women, stand up for yourself, go for it, call people out. We have to.”  Eileen and Gwen have never stopped fighting for equality. In February they were on the Bafta red carpet with actress Gemma Arterton, who starred in the West End musical version of Made in Dagenham. They wore black alongside the star in support of the Time’s Up movement against sexual harassment. They believe tomorrow’s anniversary is an important opportunity to speak out for what they so passionately believe in – especially coming as it does in the centenary year of women getting the vote. Although they shrug off any &shysuggestion that they were personally courageous, back in 1968 it was undoubtedly brave to walk out of Ford.  Support was not always forthcoming – especially when their actions led to the plant closing down and the men getting laid off too, leaving hundreds of families strapped for cash. But they both say they never doubted. “It was difficult but we had to do it,” says Eileen. “We had no hesitation. We all got together, we asked for a meeting, hands were shown and out we walked. We were very angry. Although looking back you wonder how you did do it.” The situation the women were fighting was around grading rather than pay, initially. Despite their job requiring two years’ training, the female machinists were classified as unskilled B-grade workers, the same as floor sweepers, with the equivalent pay and pensions to cleaners.  Every year they would ask to be re-classified as C-grade semi-skilled workers, which is how men with &shyequivalent training were graded. But each year they were turned down. “We had skills the same as the men,” Gwen says. “Yet we were classed the same as the teenage boys who swept the floor.” The final straw was the discovery that some male workers were being paid extra to work on the machines at night – while women were forbidden from working nights or overtime. Both women were married and had children, but say they were lucky that their husbands did not work at Ford, so one source of income kept coming in during the strike.  Both men were supportive – Eileen says her husband would put the tea on when she went off to protests. “He knew we were fighting for our rights,” she says. However, other families were not so lucky, which is why some hostility crept in. “Some said, ‘Get back to work’,” recalls Eileen. “They said we were putting the men out of work. We had to let it go over our heads.” Ultimately, for all their efforts, the women won only a partial victory. Employment Secretary Barbara Castle promised a pay rise bringing them up to 92% of the unskilled men’s wage – an improvement on their existing 85%, but still far from equal pay or the grading change they demanded. Gwen says the women had little choice but to accept the deal.

title: michael gove slammed claiming poor
story: NewsMichael Gove slammed for claiming poor people eat junk food to find "solace" in their "difficult lives"Critics have lined up to explain to the environment secretary the difficulty of paying for healthy food for people on low incomes&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent15:52, 6 JUN 2018Updated19:13, 6 JUN 2018NewsHe said people with less money find comfort in unhealthy foods (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMichael Gove has been slammed for claiming poor people eat junk food to find “solace” in their “difficult lives”. Critics have lined up to explain to the environment secretary the difficulty of paying for healthy food for people on low incomes. Mr Gove, who heads the government department in charge of food, said people with less money can find comfort in unhealthy foods. He said: “If you have got a difficult life and you have less money, then one of the things that can be a source of comfort, solace and pleasure will be buying and eating and consuming food that is not always going to be best for you in the long term.” Labour’s education chief Angela Rayner, who has spoken before about her family’s struggle to put food on the table when she was growing up, hit out at Mr Gove for being out of touch.  She said: “No Michael food choice is severely restricted to those who suffer poverty it’s mostly based on cost, those who are well off financially can “choose” from a wide range of healthy food options”. Alison Garnham chief executive of the Child Poverty Action Group told the Evening Standard: “Certainly food that is rich in nutrients is generally more expensive but the real story here is that more and more families are forced to use food banks - not for solace but for a square meal - because they don’t have enough money to live on.

title: more delays northern rail jeremy
story: News'More delays than Northern Rail!' Jeremy Corbyn slams Theresa May's Brexit chaos as she struggles for answers in PMQs clash"Which will last longer, the Northern Rail franchise or her premiership?" the Labour leader declared in a withering Prime Minister's Questions&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter12:33, 6 JUN 2018Updated12:48, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn today slammed Theresa May's chaotic Brexit negotiations declaring they've suffered more delays than Network Rail.  The Labour leader claimed the Tory government had ripped up its own timetable, just like our shambolic privatised railways in a withering PMQs clash.  He added: Which will last longer, the Northern Rail franchise or her premiership?  Mr Corbyn surprised onlookers by devoting this week's Prime Minister's Questions to Brexit - despite a battle erupting in his own party.  This morning Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer was forced to slap down unhelpful Labour MPs who want to stay in the 'soft Brexit' EEA zone. But Mr Corbyn insisted it was the Conservatives who were split - and Mrs May dodged a string of his questions.  The Prime Minister refused to say when her crucial White Paper, outlining her plan for Britain's relationship with the EU, will be published. She insisted she agrees with Brexit Secretary David Davis after reports he is fed up of slow progress and has had to redraft the White Paper five times. She refused to answer whether it will be published before this month's EU summit and whether MPs will have a chance to debate it first. She refused to say what progress had been made in choosing between the government's two current options for customs.  She also refused to deny Mr Corbyn's claims that the government was considering a bonkers 10-mile 'buffer zone' along the Irish border. But she did answer one question - whether she still intends to leave the EU in March 2019 and complete a transition period before 2021. Yes, the Prime Minister replied in a rare one-word answer. Mr Corbyn told MPs: When it comes to Brexit, this government has delivered more delays and more cancellations than Northern Rail. The government's white paper is delayes. Its customs proposals have been cancelled. And it’s ripped up its own timetable - just like our shambolic privatised railways.  This government’s incompetence threatens our economy, businesses, jobs and our communities. So my question to the Prime Minister is this - which will last longer, the Northern Rail franchise or her premiership? In return Theresa May repeatedly demanded Jeremy Corbyn rule out backing a second EU referendum - which he failed to do. The last time I looked at the order paper it said 'Prime Minister's Question Time', he complained.

title: watch floundering theresa refuse three
story: NewsWatch floundering Theresa May refuse THREE TIMES to answer a simple question on Brexit during PMQs pummelling"Is she unable to negotiate for the UK because she’s negotiating with her own cabinet?"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter13:14, 6 JUN 2018Updated16:54, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May refused THREE times to answer a simple question on her Brexit plan today, as she took a pummelling at PMQs . The Prime Minister has promised a “detailed, ambitious and precise” government White Paper, outlining her plan for Britains’ future relationship with the EU. The paper was intended to put Britain on the front foot when it comes to the next crucial set of negotiations on the final Brexit deal. But sustained Cabinet infighting is reported to have delayed the publication of the paper, as Mrs May’s senior ministers failed to agree on the finer points of our relationship with the customs union and the Northern Irish border.  As a result, there are rumblings that the paper won’t be published until AFTER the forthcoming European Commission summit - which begins on June 28th. Which is pretty awkward. And the Prime Minister today repeatedly refused to put a date on the plan’s publication.  First Jeremy Corbyn asked not once, but twice for a date. She refused to answer whether it would be published the summit or whether MPs will have a chance to debate it first. Later in PMQs, Labour MP Steve Reed gave her a third chance to answer the question.   Who won PMQs? Jeremy Corbyn delivers a Brexit bashing to a leaden-footed Theresa May  He said: “The cabinet agreed to publish a Brexit white paper ahead of this month’s crunch EU council meeting, to allow the government to negotiate. The Brexit Secretary said it would be detailed, ambitious and precise. “So will she confirm whether the Brexit White Paper will be published before the EU council meeting, or is she unable to negotiate for the UK because she’s negotiating with her own cabinet?”  Again, Mrs May refused to answer, saying: “What the Government said is that we will be publishing a White Paper, which will be detailed and ambitious, and we will do just that.” The government's embroiled in a row over its Brexit customs 'backstop'.  So what is it? It's a backup plan that will carry on some EU customs rules in the UK, after December 2020, if there's no deal. It is designed to stop ports grinding to a halt and Northern Ireland setting up border posts, which could lead to violence. But Brexiteers don't like it because it has no set end date. They fear it will trap Britain in purgatory, half-in, half-out the EU, for years. The backstop drawn up by the EU, back in March, would have kept Northern Ireland aligned with EU customs rules. Prime Minister Theresa May said this was unacceptable, because it drives a wedge between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. So she drew up Britain's own backstop plan, which it's thought will continue some EU customs rules across the whole of the UK. She now has to persuade the EU to accept this - because she has already signed up to follow the EU plan until there's a better way forward. The reason it's so important is simple. As time ticks on, the backstop will become less of a Plan B and more of a Plan A. It'll turn from backstop... to frontstop.

title: brave woman born butterfly child
story: NewsBrave woman born a 'butterfly' child reveals horrific reality of condition from NO fingerprints or skin on back to constant 'bubble wrap' blistersPHOTOS AND VIDEO OF A MEDICAL NATURE INCLUDED. Courageous Heather Skerry, 27,has battled skin cancer six times and even gets blisters down her throat - but she remains defiant&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter09:02, 6 JUN 2018Updated11:25, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor Heather Skerry, a trip abroad can prove complicated. But it's not because the brave 27-year-old is afraid of flying or has a habit of getting lost in new places. It's because she is one of the few people in the world with no fingerprints - which has led to problems at airports. It's interesting when you try to go to America and they try and take your fingerprints and you say you haven't got any, said Heather. I went to New York with my mum in 2005 and it was our turn to show our passports. Mum did her fingerprints and when it came to me I said 'I don't have any fingerprints'. He said 'Don't be silly, everybody has fingerprints'. I showed him my hands and he just looked shocked and tried to find me on his computer. He said 'Amputee?' I said, 'No, I've got hands, they're here. I just don't have any fingerprints'. I was taken off to a police room and I was absolutely terrified and burst into tears. Heather was born a 'butterfly child' - a term given to children with a rare condition that makes the skin so fragile it's compared to the wings of a butterfly.  She has had no skin on her back for 21 years and gets up every morning knowing the day ahead involves hours of bandage changes to protect her open wounds. She regularly wakes up with new blisters that have grown overnight like bubblewrap and need to be popped with sterilised needles. And her daily routine involves attaching a tube to her stomach that feeds her for 10 hours as she sleeps at night. Heather also has to put a lens in her right eye every day after an infected blister ate away at her own in 2007, forcing her to have a corneal transplant. But despite her struggles, she remains incredibly defiant. It affects my life from the minute I get up in the morning to the minute I go to bed, she said. I get the odd comments when I'm out on the streets like 'urgh' but it's ignorance. She added: On bad days I'm grumpy and I cry. I don't do anything, I just cry and think 'why me?'  There are days when I want to give up. But then I have to have to accept it and have a reality check as it could be worse. Heather's mum Wendy was shocked and heartbroken when her baby emerged with no skin on her left hand or right foot, and doctors explained her condition. Heather has recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (EB), a skin disorder that causes it to become very fragile and creates painful blisters with any trauma or friction. The life-limiting condition also means she gets blisters inside her eyes and down her throat - a terrifying reality as it means her throat can close over and she needs surgery to open it out again. My back is red raw Research has shown that people with some types of EB face a hugely increased risk of an aggressive and ultimately fatal form of skin cancer, squamous cell carcinoma, according to the charity DEBRA, which supports people with the disorder and their families. They say it tends to occur at sites of increased blistering and scarring but research into the precise link between skin cancer and EB is ongoing.  Heather, from Swindon, has had the disease six times in the last two years.  She has recently had an operation to remove skin affected by cancer on her neck and has this month been given the all clear - for now. She says EB is the biggest condition no one has ever heard of - yet it shapes her life and means she plans her every move meticoulously. Growing up she has learnt to cope with staring, people complaining about her being in hot tubs and pools, accusations that her mum has let her get sunburnt, and struggles to be intimate in relationships. But Heather is unafraid of EB, is determined to raise awareness of it and help DEBRA.Explaining her condition to Mirror, Heather said: I haven't got any skin on my back, it's been open since I was six and has never healed in 21 years.  My back is red raw and sometimes it’s described as looking like a piece of liver. It’s sore and very itchy. I’m not supposed to scratch it, but I do sometimes which blisters and rips it. My hands are one of the worst areas, I don’t have any nails from where the skin on my hands has retracted - that's why they're so small. I also don't have any fingerprints. People are shocked and laugh, saying I could rob a bank. My arms don’t go straight because of the creases and scarring I have that restricts the skin. My feet are also different sizes - my right is a child size 12 and my left is an adult size 3. EB affects my skin internally and externally. I even get blisters in my eyes.  EB is life limiting, and it usually kills at quite a young age. With dystrophic there isn't an average age for life expectancy, it depends, everybody is different. Before Heather was born, her mum had no idea she would have EB. It was only when she came out with no skin on her left hand and right foot - which eventually healed on their own- that doctors diagnosed her. The charity DEBRA supported Wendy, 64, and put her in touch with parents of other sufferers so she could make sense of her daughter's condition. It was shocking for my mum, Heather said, revealing what she's learnt about her childhood. She’s told me I used to scream throughout the dressing changes.  It was horrible and heartbreaking for my mum when I'd cry. As a child, mum wanted me to be as independent as possible but wanted to protect me as well. I couldn’t just go out with my friends because I needed help with my wheelchair. I used to swim but I just can’t anymore because my back just hurts too much. When Heather was six she had a gastronomy peg - a feeding tube - put into her stomach because she only weighed two and a half stone. She has used it every night since and it gives her a litre of a special ‘milk’ which contains the fibres, vitamins and minerals she needs to survive. Dr Helen Philips, Global Head of Medical Affairs for Amryt Pharma, said: “It’s estimated that there are more than 500,000 people living with EB worldwide, including around 2,000 people managed in specialist centres in the UK.  EB can be overwhelming and psychologically devastating to live with for both children and their carers.  Parents regularly find themselves as their child’s nurse and main carer, having to go through the difficult routine of changing bandages and dressing wounds while watching their child suffer with intolerable pain.  While significant advancements have been made in the development of therapies aimed at correcting the underlying genetic defects seen in EB, with the expectation that a cure for the disease will be developed in the long term, currently there is no cure for the condition.  Current wound care management involves daily or regular dressing changes to protect the skin, encourage healing and prevent infection.  Depending on disease severity, dressing changes can take several hours each day, often requiring the use of prescription medications to manage their excruciating pain.  The greatest need of those living with EB, and their carers, is to access better ways to manage the daily consequences of their condition, especially their wounds which are often associated with unbearable itch, pain and frequently become infected.  A cure is definitely something to aspire to achieving but short-term solutions are a priority – it is about the ‘here and now’.” As this tube goes into her stomach, she must lie on her back - and the constant friction between the bedsheets and her skin is why her back has never healed.  Her neck is also affected and “anywhere that can rub, including the creases of my elbows, the backs of my legs where I sit down, my hips and armpits, Heather says. The friction from seams of clothing or anyone bumping into her when she's out can cause blisters or rip the skin off. There are days when I want to give up The young woman also has a restrictive oesophagus and narrow throat so has to be careful with what she eats. She is able to digest soft food but scratchy or chewy foods - for example crisps or steak- can scar her throat and cause it to contract. Until now, she's had six operations to release her throat after it has tightened.  Heather's mum helps her with the process of changing any bandages that need re-dressing and to pop any blisters. She applies treatment creams in the morning and has medication to control the pain throughout the day. The morning changes only take about 20 minutes, she says. But every evening her entire back is re-bandaged, a process which takes about two hours. She also has to put her eye drops in as part of her routine.  Heather, who has had several administrative jobs in the past but is currently focusing on her treatment, says: A blister breaks down into a wound - if I don’t feel it, it can be two or three times the size by the morning. If they rip, they need to be dressed. “It’s like bubble wrap, when you pierce it, it deflates. “I wouldn’t get to sleep without my medication, it puts me in a relaxed state. But I still get pain throughout the night. Doing the bandages is part of my daily life. I've never known anything different. It's painful but I'm used to the pain. It's just physically and mentally exhausting It's never going to change so I can't mope - it's not going to heal it. Throughout the day, Heather says she needs somebody with her to help with her wheelchair. She is able to walk around the house but for longer distances uses her chair. She has to plan outings around dressing changes, and is limited to only going away with people who she knows, trusts and can help with her routine.  Heather says one of the things she's had to deal with is people staring and making complaints about her. When I was younger on holiday people would tut and assume my mum had let me get sunburnt, she revealed. One complaint that sticks in my head was on a trip to Florida in 2009. There was a couple in the hot tub and after we got in, they got out. The manager then came and said to my mum 'what's wrong with her, maybe she shouldn't be in a hot tub'. But my mum explained I was more likely to catch something from others than the other way round. It really hurt- to have somebody complain that I could be contagious was so hurtful. When I was 13 someone complained about me being in a pool in Spain as well which was so hurtful, she added. My mum carried leaflets in different languages on holiday to give to people and explained to children that I was born with poorly skin but that I was going to have it for life but that it’s OK.  Mum is incredible, I think that's where I get my strength from.  Heather has several other people who help her including her best friend Carly, Lorraine who is like her 'second mum' and her first friend Nikii. She is currently single but has had relationships in the past, although she says maintaining them has been difficult. Heather explained: The last one ended as I feel it was too much to deal with. EB is a massive part of my life and expecting somebody to bring that into their day to day life is quite a big thing. In relationships, the intimacy is difficult because I'm not comfortable with my body. I'm not dying. I'm still incredibly fit The thing Heather finds most difficult to deal with though is the regular occurrence of skin cancer. She has had 15 operations in the last two and a half years after biopsies on lumps, abnormal scabs and blisters showed she had cancer on her right knee, right hand, her neck and her foot. The last surgery was on her neck at the start of this month, and she's relieved to have been given the all-clear.

title: her first word da da
story: News'Her first word was da-da... it's heartbreaking': Grieving young mum wrote suicide note to baby daughter after childhood sweetheart diedMarshall Arnott, 20, was killed alongside two friends in a horrific van crash in Cornwall - leaving little Isla without a dad and making every day without him a battle for mum Elley Taylor&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByGayle McDonaldMiranda Blazeby09:59, 6 JUN 2018Updated11:52, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving young mum mourning the death of her childhood sweetheart has described how she wrote her baby girl a suicide note in her darkest hours. On June 5 last year, Elley Taylor arrived at Derriford Hospital in Plymouth expecting to find her boyfriend, 20-year-old Marshall Arnott with a few broken bones.  He had been travelling home from work with two friends when their van overturned on the A38 in averse weather conditions.  The three men, who were aged under 25, were all killed. Now a year on, 20-year-old Elley Taylor, mum to Marshall's daughter Isla, has described how each day since his death has been a battle.  She was already suffering from post-natal depression at the time of the crash which made the trauma of losing Marshall and their dreams of living happily ever after even worse.  “You can’t sugar coat it,” she told Plymouth Live .  But she’s determined to be a good mother and says that Isla, who looks just like her dad, has got her though the darkest time of her life. Isla was just four months old when Marshall, along with his two friends Zachary Graham and Trevor Gorman were killed. “It was horrible,” Elley said. “All I wanted to do was run away and breathe but I had a baby to look after.  “Everyone says to me ‘It’s such a brilliant thing that you’ve got Isla - she’ll help you get though it’. “I had problems having a baby before so it was a really big thing for us. I was so thankful and so grateful but it almost felt unfair. “As soon as I had the baby something awful happened. I hated the world for a long time. “I spent all that time trying for a baby, I had operations for it, and then I had a baby but I lose him. “Even though it is a blessing and I couldn’t have done it without Isla, everyone else got to grieve – if they wanted to sleep for two weeks they could, if they wanted to cry they could cry if they wanted to go and forget it on a night out they could, but I spent the nights doing night feeds on my own for God knows how long. Elley first met Marshall, her affectionately nicknamed Marshmallow, at school aged 16.  They were “obsessed” with one another and the only time they ever spent apart was when she was in hospital. She says: “I loved that idea that I could say to my kids when I grew up that we were together since we were 16. “I used to say I was so fortunate that I found him so young. He was everything I ever wanted. I felt so lucky. I couldn’t fault him in any way. “He was an amazing dad and an amazing family, an amazing brother and an amazing son.”  Since Marshall was killed in the crash, Elley has described each day as a battle and revealed she has even had to fight suicidal thoughts.  Fearing she would one day take her own life to be with Marshall, she wrote a note to Isla explaining why.  “It was on my mind so strongly for so long. I was going down to the grave every day. It was horrible that he was there and I was here, she said. “It got to the point where I felt so empty. “People say it gets better in time but it doesn’t. You just learn not to cry so much. You learn to suffer in silence in a way. That pain will never go. “I want to be with him now. That’s a daily challenge for me to get through each day. There was a really bad time when I wrote a letter to Isla and I wrote a letter to my brother Curtis. “He was so happy. He was so loving and caring – he loved everything that he had in his life. I had post-natal depression. I was already very low and very depressed.  “Being at his grave and taking Isla down there. I used to think ‘why are you down there and I’m up here?’ “The plan was to live happily ever after. This feeling went on for so long. I wrote Isla the letter just in case. “It said that if she was reading this letter I was with daddy and it was okay. “I put it in an envelope and put it to one side.” Even now she feels she has to choose between being with her baby and being with the man she loved. “I want to be with both of them, she says. That’s a very hard thing to live with.  “I said it from the beginning – if I can chose any other way, other than him not being in that accident, that it would have been the three of us together. “I know that would have hurt a lot more people but I wouldn’t have been without him and Isla wouldn’t have been without a dad.” Despite Isla and Marshall only having a few precious months together, Elley is adamant that she will know her dad. Pictures of the young family are dotted around the flat and lovingly crafted photo albums fill the shelves. She says: “A lot of people around me didn’t like to hear his name. It was too fresh but I have his daughter – she had to know who her daddy is.  “I had to teach her so young to remember him. Now she can point him out in a photo. There’s a photo of him by the door. Every morning and every night we kiss him and say hello. “I hope he would be proud. “I feel like she was brought here and I was meant to look after her and I feel that she is looking after me. I feel like she was brought here because she knew I needed somebody. Elley is now looking to the future and has secured a place to study counselling at college in September. She hopes that by being so honest about her struggles will make other people realise they're also “allowed” to feel sad when bad things happen.

title: princess eugenie allowed social media
story: NewsWhy Princess Eugenie is allowed to be on social media but most other royals aren'tPrincess Eugenie has posted lots of brilliant photos since she joined Instagram earlier this year - including some brilliant family throwbacks&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer15:33, 6 JUN 2018Updated16:54, 6 JUN 2018News (Image: WireImage)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf there's one thing we've learnt this year, it's that Princess Eugenie LOVES a throwback picture. The young royal, who is ninth in line to the throne, joined Instagram in March and has been delighting fans with her photos ever since. She's posted pictures of her charity events as well as personal snaps of her with the family and her fianc&eacute Jack Brooksbank. But many people were a tad surprised when she popped up as a suggested friend, because the royal family are known for being incredibly strict when it comes to their private life. Most of her family aren't allowed social media accounts, and Meghan Markle had to close all of her pages down when she started dating Prince Harry.   But Eugenie isn't technically a working royal, which means she's allowed an account, reports Hello magazine .  Even though she's a member of the royal family, she doesn't spend her days attends official engagements like William, Kate and Harry. She actually has a normal job, and works at Hauser &amp Wirth, a contemporary art gallery in London. However she does do a lot of charity work, and she's shared several photos from events.  She's also shared personal family photos with funny captions, including a picture of Jack with the message: Clearly I said something funny this time! Sums up Jack in a nutshell! Her blue-ticked account has more than 173,000 followers, even though she only follows 18 people.  The lucky people on her list include her parents, the official royal accounts, several charities and her pal popstar Ellie Goulding. Her official bio reads The Official Instagram Account for Princess Eugenie with a link back to her official website.  Eugenie is set to marry her long-term boyfriend Jack later this year, in the same venue where Prince Harry and Meghan Markle tied the know last month.  Jack popped the question in Nicaragua in January.

story: NewsThe Queen is advertising for an 'army' of maids - but there's one important detail missingBack in March the household was offering £16,955-a-year to successful applicants&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor11:48, 6 JUN 2018NewsMa'am is keeping mum on one detail (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBehind every smiling and waving monarch lies an army of hardworking staff.  Grafting tirelessly behind the scenes, they are the people responsible for chauffeuring the royals around, washing the dishes, opening doors for them - even playing the bagpipes to wake them up .   So it's no surprise that the Queen is on the lookout for a small army of maids to help her live her best, most majestic life.  In fact, for the SECOND time in less than three months, she's trying maids with an eye for detail to clean and care for her palaces in London and Windsor Castle. Sound tempting? Well, there's one crucial detail missing which may inform your decision to apply.  In March the household was offering &pound16,955-a-year to successful applicants. This time round, however, there's no mention of salary. The advert reads: This is a career pathway in hospitality that will develop your housekeeping skills and expertise. Joining our professional team, you'll upkeep, clean and care for a wide range of interiors and items, ensuring they're presented to their very best.  Learning from your colleagues, you'll gain the specialist professional skills needed, always aiming for the highest standards. And you'll take care of guests and work front-of-house to support special events too. While previous housekeeping or hospitality experience is good, it's not a prerequisite. They're more after an eye for detail, organisation and teamwork.

title: royalty listers london hotel engulfed
story: NewsFrom royalty to A-listers: London hotel engulfed in flames has hosted stars including Rhianna, Taylor Swift and Prince CharlesThe Mandarin Oriental hotel in Knightsbridge is regularly frequented by the world's biggest stars&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHeather McNeill18:01, 6 JUN 2018Updated18:27, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe five-star luxury hotel ablaze in central London is a social haven for celebrities. Taylor Swift, Rhianna and Morgan Freeman are among those who have visited the Mandarin Oriental hotel. The upmarket Knightsbridge venue also hosted the Prince of Wales when he held talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping during a state visit in 2015. On Wednesday, the hotel was on fire as nearly 100 firefighters battled to control the 'massive blaze'. Robbie Williams was among hundreds who were forced to flee as the evacuation began. More than 120 firefighters were called the scene of the fire.  Its celebrity clientele in recent years include actresses Renee Zellweger and Liz Hirley. In 2009, Whitney Houston hosted a media playback of her new album at the hotel, while in 2012, Rhianna used the venue to hold a press junket to promote her new film, Battleship.  A year earlier, singer-songwriter Taylor Swift stayed at a room in the hotel during a trip to London. The venue has just received a multi-million pound refurbishment with new bedrooms, restaurants and dining spaces. It is also home to Heston Blumenthal's restaurant, Dinner.

title: teenager 15 cerebral palsy becomes
story: NewsTeenager, 15, with cerebral palsy becomes first girl to win national beauty pageant in wheelchairFrances Watkins pulled on her ballgown and put on make-up to take the stage at Teen Natural Beauty Wales and scoop the title&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByChristie BannonMartin Fricker15:18, 6 JUN 2018NewsFrances made history by winning the competition and beating dozens of other competitors (Image: WALES NEWS SERVICE)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave teenager with cerebral palsy has become the first wheelchair-user to win a national beauty pageant. Pretty Frances Watkins, 15, beat dozens of able-bodied competitors to land the top prize and make history. She was diagnosed with cerebral palsy, which affects movement and co-ordination, after being born 10 weeks premature. Despite needing a wheelchair to get around, Frances was determined to enter the beauty pageant. She pulled on her ballgown and put on make-up to take the stage at Teen Natural Beauty Wales and win the event. Her proud mum Marie Watkins, 42, described Frances' victory as “inspirational”.  She said: “I’ve always told Frances there is no such word as can't. She really is an inspiration for others. “She's living proof that in spite of her disability she can be whoever she wants to be and she's beautiful. “Frances’ life can illustrate that a person may be successful, beautiful and attractive regardless of how they move.  “She may have a disability but it doesn’t stop her loving being the centre of attention. “To win it was a dream come true. For me it's about changing people's attitudes.” Her victory came after comedian Lee Ridley won Britain's Got Talent performing as ‘Lost Voice Guy’.

title: town time forgot abandoned chinese
story: The town that time forgot: Abandoned Chinese fishing village once thriving with life is reclaimed by natureBuilt on the steep hills of Shengshan Island, 2,000 fishermen once plied their trade in the village of Houtouwan in China, hauling in their catches before selling it to locals&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary10:09, 6 JUN 2018NewsOnce bustling with life, these haunting images show the village of Houtouwan in China blanketed in a thick layer of vegetation as nature crawls into every crack and crevice of the empty stone buildings.Thousands of inhabitants moved from the Island in the early 1990s, seeking better education, jobs and healthcare - leaving only a small handful of residents to remain.The stunning pictures show how family homes once filled with the sights, sounds and smells of everyday life have since been handed back to nature.The abandoned village of Houtouwan basks in the dawn sunshine, showing the vast amounts of vegetation which have overtaken the empty buildings  (Image: AFP)1 of 10Entire facades have been turned a vibrant green as plants blanket the once bustling family homes (Image: AFP)2 of 10The village is located on a steep hill on Shengshan Island, which once saw 2,000 fishermen ply their trade (Image: AFP)3 of 10A handful of residents remain on the island, while most left in the early 1990s to seek better education, jobs and healthcare  (Image: AFP)4 of 10The lush greenery thrives as the village was 'handed to nature' when most of the residents left (Image: AFP)5 of 10An aerial shot shows the houses nestled amongst the foliage in the village  (Image: AFP)6 of 10A stunning long-shot shows the village built on the steep hillside of the island above its rocky coastline  (Image: AFP)7 of 10Hundreds of families once filled the village with sights, sounds and smells of everyday life in a busy fishing village (Image: AFP)8 of 10Entire buildings appear barely-there as greenery plasters their facades  (Image: AFP)9 of 10Houtouwan is one of 400 islands in the Shengsi archipelago (Image: AFP)10 of 10More OnAbandoned placesCommentsShow more comments

title: american burger chain to launch its first scottish outlet in dundee
story: A Hollywood-based premium burger chain is set to launch its first Scottish outlet in Dundee.Fatburger was established in southern California about 70 years, recently teaming up with Buffalo’s Express.The business recently opened its first British restaurant in London and it is now coming to Dundee.Local businessman Akky Hayat and his family are adding Fatburger Buffalo to their portfolio of restaurants.Akky and his brothers Alfy and AJ already own a Subway takeaway and were the first inThe new venture will occupy newly-fitted premises in Reform Street, close to the GDKFatburger Buffalo will seat 60 and will be open 11-11 seven days a week.The restaurant will serve up gourmet burgers ranging in size from Single to XXXL that canThe chain boasts juicy, made-to-order, boneless and bone-in chicken wings and salads toAkky Hayat said: “We are thrilled to be bringing yet more sensational foreign food flavours to“German Doner Kebab is now well-established and is a firm favorite among diners of all“Fatburger Buffalo offers an all-American treat as an alternative to what is currently availableAkky hopes that the new restaurant will be open for business by the end of September.

title: biggest ever dundee oktoberfest planned at new venue
story: This year’s Dundee Oktoberfest will be held at Slessor Gardens for the first time, headlined by chart-toppers The Magic Numbers.Taking place over three days from September 27-29, just a fortnight after the opening of the adjacent V&ampA Museum, the beer festival will also feature more than a dozen local musicians.The outdoor event, organised by the Rotary Club of Dundee, will showcase international food and drink.Previously held at Discovery Point, the event has been moved so it can grow to meet demand as it is expected to be the biggest one yet.Robert Dunn, president of the Rotary Club of Dundee, said having the festival at Slessor Gardens is a “huge step” for the charity event, which was first held in 2011.He said: “This is our biggest ever Oktoberfest and it’s great to have an act like The Magic Numbers playing.“We’re so excited. We had got too big for Discovery Point, which can hold around 800 people.“This year it will be much bigger with an estimated 2,500 to 3,000 people expected to come along over the three days.“It’s an opportunity to move here and with the opening of the V&ampA just weeks before, we’re hoping many people coming for that also decide to attend our event.“It will all be under a marquee so we’re all set, whether we get the weather or not.”Sarah Craig, Dundee City Council’s city centre manager, added: “With The Magic Numbers as well as local acts performing at Oktoberfest it will be great a great mix.”The Magic Numbers are best known for a number of hits such as Forever Lost, Love Me Like You, and Take a Chance, all released during the mid-noughties.Their biggest success came in 2005 when their self-titled album reached number seven in the UK charts.

title: calling dundee folk adventurers wanted to travel the world for new tv show
story: Dundee&#8217s adventurers are invited to apply for a new TV show that involves travelling across the world.Studio Lambert, the television company behind Gogglebox, is seeking people with a keen sense of adventure to take part in a trans-global race for a cash prize.Do you have the skills to travel off the beaten track? Could you navigate your way across the world better than anybody else? If so, this could be your journey of a lifetime.The ambitious real-world adventure series is looking for contestants to travel across the globe by whatever means they can: foot, car, bicycle, boat, bus, ferry, motorbike, horse… as long as it’s without flying.With no phones to help, it’s set to be the ultimate globe-trotting expedition. Along the way they’ll be passing through the world’s most beautiful scenery, meeting friendly locals, and immersing themselves in a kaleidoscope of different cultures.Contestants will travel alongside another contestant and a small crew. title: competition from new signing wont faze dundee goalkeeper calum ferrie
story: Jack Hamilton may have arrived at the Kilmac Stadium to battle for the No 1 jersey but that won’t dampen Calum Ferrie’s hopes in the new season.The young Dundee keeper made his debut in senior football back in April against Rangers before getting a first start between the sticks in the final match of last season.Former Port Vale goalie Ferrie impressed manager Neil McCann enough to land another year’s contract and he says he’ll do everything in his power to get more game time in the coming campaign.That’s despite former Hearts man Hamilton signing up and having last season’s No 1 choice Elliott Parish in front of him.Ferrie said: “I feel like I had a good season and when you’re having a good one you don’t want it to stop, you want to keep going.“Probably the hardest thing for me will be to come back next year to keep things going but I’ll definitely come back and be 100%.“No one can ever question my attitude – ability, question that all you want but attitude, not me.”A number of Development players making the step up to first team level at Dundee over the past season and Ferrie reckons that’ll be no different in the coming season.Gaffer Neil has had no worries throwing in untested young players if he thinks they are ready.That faith in youngsters and a clear pathway to first-team football is something Ferrie says will attract more and more talented youth players to Dundee.He added: “It really does show the gaffer’s faith in young players.“It’s fantastic to see because at a lot of other clubs, people of that age wouldn’t be in and around the first-team squad, they might be out on loan or something but playing at this level at a young age can really help you for experience.“It’s a bonus if a player can see a direct route into the first team.“That’s a major part of decisions young players make because a lot get lost at 19, 20, 21 years old, they maybe drift in an U/23s squad and never get that chance to step up.“Definitely here there is a direct route and it’s enjoyable and great to have the gaffer’s faith.“I’ve really enjoyed coming up to Dundee. It was a big move for me.“Bobby Geddes (keeper coach) has been great and the gaffer has been brilliant because he’s put faith in me to put me on the bench and play me in the last game.“That’s the biggest thing for a goalkeeper, having the manager’s faith in you.”

title: dundee people age no barrier as dundonians pick up new instruments with music academy launch
story: From a four-year-old to a 77-year-old, the visitors to Dundee Music Academy&#8217s opening weekend found age doesn&#8217t matter when it comes to learning an instrument.More than 150 people took up the offer of free music lessons to launch the Academy at Dundee Music Studios last weekend.&#8220The aim was to inspire the people of Dundee and highlight the amazing benefits of music,&#8221 organiser David Gourlay said.&#8220We were very happy with the turn out and the mix of ages was fantastic, from the youngest being four to the oldest 77, we had a great time with a lovely group of people.Music a big part of life for Dundee music tutor&#8220Each person was given the opportunity for free to try as many music lessons as they wanted in guitar, piano, drums, bass and singing.&#8221He said the feedback had been great, with lots of the people who attended booking in the following week for lessons.&#8220But the most important thing for us was seeing the enjoyment and happiness people felt whilst taking their lessons,&#8221 he said.&#8220Our team of tutors had a great weekend passing on some of their knowledge and after 22 hours of teaching for free they all agreed that they found it so rewarding that they would do it again!&#8220So we have decided that we should host this type of event numerous times throughout the year.&#8220In fact we noticed that lots of people missed out on the chance to get a free music lesson due to prior commitments and variety of different reasons so we want to offer everyone at any time the chance to book in a try a first lesson for free with any of our tutors.&#8221He said the benefits of playing music were &#8220incredible&#8221.&#8220Everyone loves music, it’s one of life’s greatest gifts but few know just how mentally, physically and emotionally rewarding it is to play an instrument.&#8220Playing an instrument increases memory, enhances coordination, teaches discipline, perseverance and patience, builds confidence, sharpens your concentration, relieves stress and allows self-expression, it creates a sense of achievement as you develop your ability, and there are so many more benefits but most of all, it’s make you happy and everyone deserves to feel happy,&#8221 he said.

title: dundee people drama students to stage legally blonde
story: A group of drama students had a day at the theatre to help them get into character.Youngsters from the Stage Academy Theatre School, Dundee, took a trip up to Aberdeen to see the Legally Blonde UK tour.Senior students from the academy will be performing their own version of Legally Blonde at the Whitehall Theatre on June 23-24.Class teacher Lauren McRuvie said: “The students thoroughly enjoyed the trip and it was made even more special when, at the end of the performance, we met professional actress Laura Harrison, who has played the role of Vivienne in the tour.“Our student Katie Stewart, who is playing Vivienne in our production, was delighted to be photographed with her.”Younger students are also gearing up for their performance of Annie Kids on the same dates.Lauren added: “All of our students are working extremely hard towards their performances.”

title: dundee people dundees mix up kids base designs on beijing
story: Kids from Mix Up Theatre had a blast at Dundee Design Parade.The kids were partnered with designer Lynsey Smiles and their chosen city was Beijing.The drama students studied the ancient Chinese art form of Peking Opera and they designed costumes, make-up and props. They also put together a movement piece.The students and teachers Stewart McLaren and Deborah Chapman had a fantastic day and loved every minute of it.Stewart said: “The design parade was a wonderful addition to the Year of Young People and Mix Up Theatre hopes to see more events like this in Dundee in the future.”Mix Up Theatre provides weekly drama classes and will be running a drama summer camp at St Martin’s Church for kids aged five-12 from July 9-13.The students will prepare for a performance on the Friday.For more information, visit the website mixuptheatre.

title: dundee people from teacher to museum volunteer every day is a chance to learn something new for pat
story: When she retired from working as a school teacher around 10 years ago, Pat Donaldson began looking for something that fitted with her interests while also giving back to the community.So, she began helping out the Verdant Works museum and eight years later is still giving up her time to help visitors to the historic mill.&#8220I was retired so I was looking for something that I was interested in, and I&#8217ve always been interested in industrial history so I just came along and had a shot at it,&#8221 she said.&#8220I&#8217m meeting loads of people from all over the world, it&#8217s a good place.&#8221Pat said her interest in history came from her time as a teacher, when it was one of the subjects she taught, and said the museum gave her a chance to continue learning about it.&#8220The 19th century industry industrial revolution was quite interesting,&#8221 she said.&#8220Sometimes you learn from visitors because they&#8217ll say something and you&#8217ll go &#8216oh I never thought about that&#8217 and you&#8217ll go and look it up.&#8221Pat, who now lives in Lawside, is originally from Elie in Fife before attending university in Dundee.She had taught at a number of schools in the area, including St Johns, Linlathen and Morgan Academy.As well as volunteering at the mill, she was also kept busy with other things such as brushing up on her German.&#8220When I was at university, friends and I decided to go hitchhiking in Germany and even then it wasn&#8217t safe,&#8221 she said.&#8220I started to teach myself German and then I went to teach in Germany, teaching English in a German school.&#8220I hadn&#8217t done it in school so I never had the basics of the grammar, so that&#8217s what I&#8217m trying to do now.&#8221She said volunteering was a great thing to do.&#8220When you&#8217re retired you have to look for things to do,&#8221 she said.&#8220Most of the volunteers here are retired, though not all of them&#8220There&#8217s definitely a benefit from doing it, because it&#8217s nice interacting with people and helping them, and when people thank you for that it&#8217s nice as well.&#8220Doing something volunteering, you&#8217re giving something back.&#8221

title: dundee people janes loved running dundee playgroup but is looking for someone to take over
story: Jane Duffy has loved her time running a Dundee playgroup but with her son ready to move on to nursery, she&#8217s looking for someone else to pick up the reins.Jane has been taking her four-year-old son Ralphy along to the Main Street Playgroup at Coldside Church for about two years, she said, and took over the running of it in January along with two other mums.Since then, they had revitalised the group and introduced a more structured programme including arts, crafts and singing.&#8220I&#8217ve loved it,&#8221 Jane said.&#8220I&#8217ve been taking my little boy Ralphy along since he was about two but it wasn&#8217t until January when I took it over along with two other mums.&#8220We&#8217ve done it between the three of us, made it a bit more structured and put on a lot more activities for the children.&#8220We done some fundraising as well and raised some money to get some more toys.&#8220We went to Togs for Tots and got some new high chairs and stuff like that.&#8221Some of the events included planting sun flowers and making plant pots for Easter.But Jane said it was time for them to move on and they were now looking for someone else to organise and run the group.&#8220Unfortunately the two mums I was doing it with got jobs,&#8221 Jane said.&#8220They left two weeks ago so I&#8217ve been doing it on my own which is quite hard.&#8220But Ralphy here is about to go to nursery, so I won&#8217t be able to do it any more because he&#8217ll be going to nursery full time.&#8220And it would just be a shame to see all that hard work go, and it&#8217s good for the children.&#8221She said they have had up to 21 children come along to the group on a Monday and Thursday, although the days could be changed.&#8220It&#8217s good for the mum&#8217s as well, they get a chat get a cup of tea,&#8221 she said.&#8220We just need somebody keen to take it over and to continue it. It&#8217d actually be good for a couple of people, I think it&#8217d be good to have a group doing it.&#8221

title: dundee people lord provost presents wreath to dundee students ahead of belgium visit
story: Lord Provost Ian Borthwick visited Grove Academy to hand over a wreath which he signed on behalf of the city to mark the centenary of the end of the First World War.The wreath will be taken to Belgium in September when 45 pupils and five members of staff will be visiting memorials to the fallen.The visit will culminate in the laying of the wreath at the Last Post ceremony at the Menin Gate in Ypres.John Anderson, principal teacher of history at Grove, said: “Pupils visit every year but with 2018 being 100 years since the end of the war we wanted to do something more symbolic.”
